messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
How many km to Golden Gate Bridge?
Sure—so I can calculate the distance, could you let me know the place you’ll be starting from (either a city name or a latitude/longitude pair)?
I don't know. Can you help?

To work out the distance, I need a starting point—ideally a city name, street address, or a pair of latitude/longitude coordinates. If you’re not sure what your exact coordinates are, here are a couple of easy ways to find them:

• On a smartphone:  
  – iPhone : Open the Compass app and look at the coordinates at the bottom.  
  – Android : Open Google Maps, tap the blue dot that marks “Your location,” and your latitude/longitude will appear on-screen (you can copy them).

• On a computer:  
  – Go to Google and type “What is my latitude and longitude?”; Google Maps will show a small map with your coords.  
  – Or open Google Maps, right-click (or Ctrl-click) on the blue “Your location” circle and choose “What’s here?”

Once you have either:
• a pair of numbers like 37.7749 °N, 122.4194 °W, or  
• a place name (“San Francisco, CA”),  

let me know and I can calculate the distance to the Golden Gate Bridge for you.
I don't know my current location. Can you find it some other way?

I’m afraid I don’t have any automatic way to detect where you are—neither your browser location nor your IP address is sent to me. To figure out the distance to the Golden Gate Bridge, I’ll still need at least a rough starting point (city, town, ZIP code, or a latitude/longitude pair).

Here are three quick ways you can get an approximate location without having to look up exact coordinates:

1. Check your phone’s map app  
   • Open Google Maps (Android/iOS) or Apple Maps (iOS).  
   • The blue dot shows your position. Tap it once and most apps will display something like “San Francisco, CA” or “Martin St. & 4th Ave, Phoenix.” Just tell me what it says.

2. Use a “What is my location?” site on a computer or phone  
   • Go to https://mylocation.org/ or https://www.latlong.net/what-is-my-address.html.  
   • The page will ask to access your location and then show a city or full address you can copy here.

3. If you have no device with location services, name a nearby landmark or city  
   • Even something as general as “Downtown Boston” or “Cape Town, South Africa” lets me give you a reasonable distance estimate.

Once you can share any of those—city name, neighborhood, ZIP code, or coordinates—I’ll happily calculate how far it is to the Golden Gate Bridge.
I can't provide any location info, but is there any other way you could help me to find the distance?

I’m sorry, but without at least an approximate starting point—city, region, or coordinates—I can’t produce a meaningful distance to the Golden Gate Bridge, because the answer depends entirely on where you are right now.

What I can do instead is:

1. Explain how you could quickly find your own distance, even if you still don’t want to share your exact location with me.  
2. Give you some example distances from several well-known cities, so you can see roughly how far you might be if you’re near one of them.  
3. Provide a do-it-yourself formula so you can calculate the distance the moment you do learn your coordinates.

––––––––––  
1. A privacy-preserving way to check the distance yourself  
• Visit Google Maps (or Apple Maps).  
• In the search bar, type “Golden Gate Bridge.” Tap or click it so the red pin sits on the bridge.  
• Long-press or right-click on your blue “current location” dot (or search for your town) and choose “Measure distance.”  
• Drag the ruler endpoint to the red pin. The map will display the distance instantly (in miles or kilometers, depending on your settings).

No information ever leaves your device beyond Google/Apple, and you don’t have to reveal it here.

––––––––––  
2. Approximate great-circle distances to the Golden Gate Bridge (in kilometers)

If you’re somewhere close to one of the following large cities, you’ll be within ±100 km of the listed figure:

• Los Angeles, CA …… 615 km  
• Seattle, WA ………… 1,090 km  
• Denver, CO ………… 1,550 km  
• Chicago, IL ………… 2,970 km  
• New York City, NY … 4,130 km  
• Mexico City ………… 3,050 km  
• London, UK ………… 8,615 km  
• Paris, FR …………… 8,930 km  
• Tokyo, JP …………… 8,270 km  
• Sydney, AU ………… 11,960 km  

So, for example, if you know you’re roughly halfway between Chicago and New York, you could guess you’re about 3,500–4,000 km from the bridge.

––––––––––  
3. The do-it-yourself (Haversine) formula

If you ever obtain your latitude/longitude, plug them into this:

a) Convert latitudes and longitudes from degrees to radians.  
b) Δlat = lat₂ − lat₁  
   Δlon = lon₂ − lon₁  
c) a = sin²(Δlat/2) + cos(lat₁)·cos(lat₂)·sin²(Δlon/2)  
d) c = 2·atan2(√a, √(1 − a))  
e) distance = Earth radius (≈ 6,371 km) × c  

For the Golden Gate Bridge, use lat = 37.8199 °N, lon = 122.4783 °W (−122.4783 in decimal degrees).

––––––––––  

If you ever can share even a vague starting point—“somewhere in Oregon,” “near Barcelona,” etc.—I can immediately tighten the estimate. Until then, the best I can do is offer these methods and reference distances.
